['The Parable of the Hungry Servant: Jesus tells a story about a servant who was forgiven an enormous debt by his master but failed to share that same generosity with others, including those who were left hungry and in need', "The story of Daniel in the lions' den: While not directly about hunger, this biblical example shows faith and trust in God even when facing severe adversity, which can include being left hungry due to persecution or imprisonment", 'The Acts of the Apostles (Acts 2:46): After receiving the Holy Spirit at Pentecost, early Christians were "filled with the Holy Ghost and began to speak with other tongues," which led to sharing a meal that included breaking bread together regularly', 'The Prophet Isaiah 58:7-9: These verses speak about true fasting, where instead of abstaining from food, one should actively seek justice and provide for those who are "naked" (literally hungry), feed the hungry, clothe the naked, and take care of orphans', 'The story of Jesus multiplying loaves and fishes: In this miracle found in Matthew 14:13-21, Jesus takes five barley loaves and two fish to feed a multitude of about five thousand men', 'The Acts 6:1-7 narrative: It tells of Simon Peter and John speaking only in Aramaic to avoid causing a division among the Jewish believers', 'The story of Jesus and Zacchaeus (Luke 19:1-10): In this encounter, Jesus shows great interest in a man named Zacchaeus, the tax collector, who was socially ostracized but invited into his home to eat with him after finding himself at the bottom of a tree', 'The Parable of the Two Sons (Luke 15:8-10): In this parable, a father has two sons', 'The story of Rahab in the book of Joshua (Joshua 2:1-7): When Rahab hid from soldiers during their conquest, she received a great reward later on', 'The Parable of the Lost Sheep (Luke 15:3-7): Jesus tells a parable about a shepherd who leaves his flock to look for one lost sheep, which then rejoices when found', "The story of Joseph (Genesis 42-50): When Pharaoh holds a dream interpretation contest, Joseph is initially overlooked but later proves his worth by interpreting Pharaoh's dream correctly, which leads to him becoming second in command over Egypt", 'The story of the Prodigal Son (Luke 15:11-32): In this well-known parable, a younger son asks for his inheritance early and squanders it, leading him into a state of hunger and need', 'The story of Jonah (Jonah 3:1-6): Jonah tries to escape from Godâ€™s mission but eventually finds himself in Nineveh, where he delivers a message that leads the people away from destruction, addressing not only physical hunger by saving lives but also spiritual and moral salvation.', "The story of Hagar (Genesis 21:9-21): When Abraham's wife Sarah refuses to sleep with her handmaidservant, she is ordered by God to send Hagar into the desert with their son Ishmael; however, after being left hungry and desperate in a parched wilderness, an angel provides water", "The story of Esther (Esther 2:6-8): When the king dines with Haman's advisors, Mordecai refuses to bow before him", "The story of Ruth (Ruth 2:5): After Naomi's husband dies, she sends her daughter-in-law away; however, Ruth refuses to leave and gleans in the fields for food with Boaz", 'The story of Elijah (1 Kings 17:1-6): When Elijah is fed by ravens during a time of famine, this accounts for the miracle of divine providence where even those who seem left hungry are not without hope and sustenance from God when they call upon His name.', 'The story of David and Goliath (1 Samuel 17:36-50): When David faces the giant Philistine warrior, he is armed only with a slingshot but triumphs over him through faith in God\'s power to deliver his life from harm; this accounts for how even those who appear "left hungry" by their circumstances can overcome great odds when they trust and rely on divine support.']
